During our research, we have asked the public about their support for various farming practices. Opinions varied significantly, but chicken cages emerged as the practice with the highest support for a ban. These cages were viewed as having the least necessity and one of the highest levels of harm. Conversely, farming animals for food had the highest perceived necessity, the lowest harm rating, and the least support for a ban.

This highlighted an intriguing inverse relationship between perceived harm, necessity, and support for a ban. Specifically, the greater the perceived harm and the lower the perceived necessity, the stronger the support for a ban.

By targeting policies that already have high levels of public support, it should be much easier to mobilise around the issue and have the policy passed at a national level. Additionally, by emphasizing the harm and redundancy of cruel practices in our messaging, we can influence public support for bans.

description:
Humans are caring by nature and if we see another animal in need, we automatically want to help them. Recently, a whole community in Bolivia exemplified this by coming together to assist a stranded pink dolphin and her baby. The dolphins became a local attraction and the residents waved goodbye with flags and cheers as they were released into the Isiboro river. 🐬 ✨ 
 
Stories like this are powerful. They help people see our animal cousins as part of an ‘us’, rather than an ‘other’. They reinforce many helpful narratives, like kinship, good neighbours, altruism and animal freedom. And they show humans living up to their values, which can help connect with people’s aspirational identities and inspire them to do the same.

Raku, a male orangutan, made headlines when he was seen chewing a medicinal plant into a paste and applying it to a wound on his cheek, which then healed completely within a month. This marks the first time a free-living animal has been observed treating an injury with medicine.

Biologist Dr. Isabella Laumer commented, “I think in the next few years we will discover even more behaviours and more abilities that are very human-like.”

This story reinforces the 𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀 narrative, highlighting the intelligence and inner lives of our animal cousins. Our own research has found that this narrative is incredibly persuasive because it helps people build empathy and understand that other animals are very similar to humans in many ways.

description:
For our narrative sneak peek today, we’re excited to share insights from our research on trust in different groups to prioritise the welfare of farmed animals in the UK. 🐄🐖

We asked our participants which groups they trusted "a lot" or "a great deal," and the results were as follows:

𝐇𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐥𝐲 𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝: Vets, animal welfare charities, and animal rights groups (over 50%). 🩺
𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐥𝐲 𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝: Farmers (42%). 🚜
𝐋𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭: Corporations (13.5%), politicians (3.6%), the government (8.5%), and the government's enforcement of animal welfare laws (11.4%). 🏛️

These findings provide potential opportunities for our framing of the 'enemy’ in future messaging. Due to systemic shortcomings and a lack of accountability, the public is already inclined to distrust corporations, politicians, and the government when it comes to animal welfare. 

Let us know your thoughts in the comments! 👇

Can principles like the Golden Rule – treating others as we would wish to be treated – be applied for the rights and freedoms of animals? 🐑

Don't you agree that similar to humans, all animals have unique abilities, personalities and feelings? 🦌

As we gather with @directactioneverywhere, we invite you to join us for this 𝐞𝐱𝐜𝐥𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝟏-𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐡𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐧𝐞𝐱𝐭 𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐲.💥

📌 December 18th, Monday
⏰ 6:30 - 7:30 PM (GMT) | 10:30 - 11:30 AM (PT)
⤷ Registration link is in our profile and story.

In 2016, DxE investigators openly rescued a chicken named Qing from a cage that had deformed her feet. 🐓 But their compassion was criminalised and ultimately led to the incarceration of animal rescuer #WayneHsiung last month. 🚨

🙌 Can the movement make this repression backfire? Can we turn animal freedom into an international debate? If yes, how?

We're gathering with Direct Action Everywhere (DxE), whose investigators were recently arrested for rescuing someone neglected and suffering, to reveal the answers to these questions. 🗝️ @cassie_dxe, Communications Lead at @directactioneverywhere, and 21-year-old UC Berkeley student and Founder of Happy Hen Animal Sanctuary, @zoe_rooster, will join the conversation to summarise what happened and detail the stories of Qing, Wayne, and three other DxE animal rescuers who were arrested on felony warrants outside the courthouse, including Zoe herself. 🏛️

During the webinar, Mark Westcombe from @animal.think.tank will discuss the importance of escalation and the backfire effect, providing historical examples, key learning points, and opportunities. 💡 Together, we'll contribute to the question of how we, as a movement, can be prepared to respond and build a larger narrative around events like this to potentially create a whirlwind moment.

🎟️ With less than a week remaining, register now and get your free ticket for this exclusive session. 

⤷ Registration link is in our profile and story

"You lock eyes with her. You can see she’s in pain and she’s trapped. You know that if you don’t get help, she’ll most likely die. So you contact the authorities, sharing photos and videos, so they understand the urgency of the situation. But they refuse to help.

What do you do? Do you walk away? Or do you help free her?" asks Natalie Braine, our Narrative Researcher at Animal Think Tank.

📖 This beautifully written blog is available for you to read (⤷ The link is in our profile.). Learn more about why #WayneHsiung has been imprisoned, the story of the rescue chicken Qing, and how this open rescue by @directactioneverywhere  has sparked an international debate on animal freedom.

✊ We stand in support of @waynehhsiung and the recently arrested DxE activists: @zoe_rooster, Conrad de Jesus, and Rocky Chau. We hold #RighttoRescue, to help those who are suffering. ❤️‍🩹🐓

We were at @vegfestuk London last week and absolutely loved being back! 💚 We had a great time, meeting old friends, making new ones, and enjoying delicious vegan food. 🍕

💡 Our Governance Lead, Dilan Fernando, ran an interactive workshop for those who want to do more to help animals and helped them explore how they could step into their power and contribute to the movement in their own authentic ways. 

🎯 Our Direction Lead, Dr. Laila Kassam, gave a talk on three key ingredients needed to build a mass movement that has the power to win animal freedom and how we are applying these in our own work. 

🔎 And finally, our Narrative Researcher, Natalie Braine, gave a talk on our narrative work and shared the persuasive narratives our public research and testing has uncovered so far.

Our talks reached nearly 100 people 🚀, consolidating relationships with key players and laying the groundwork for exciting collaborations, particularly integrating narrative work into upcoming projects. It warms our hearts to hear that attendees found hope and direction in our discussions.

We participated in the Movement Unity panel alongside representatives of the 
@hunt_saboteurs, @theoriginalvegansociety, @plantbasedunis and @plantbasedtreaty. The panel had a lively discussion on the ways these groups are already collaborating and identified further opportunities to work together. 🤝 We left with some great new contacts and ideas to follow up with. 

On the panel, Tim Barford, founder of Vegfest, shared the exciting news that next year he's planning to organise a 1 day summit with the aim of further developing collaboration in the movement. He rightly sees movement unity as key to our success and power, as do we. ✊

Thank you Vegfest for having us! 💙 It's had a massive impact, much of which we'll never know about. We look forward to whatever comes next. 

.
.
.

We were thrilled to have @paxfauna as our guest in our recent webinar! 📌 Here are 𝟑 𝐤𝐞𝐲 𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐚𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 that shed light on crucial insights:

🔑 𝐅𝐫𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐬 𝐊𝐞𝐲 🔑

▶ The tension exists where a significant portion of people support animal freedom in principle but not at the cost of personal choice.
▶ The issue lies in framing—how information is presented shapes cognitive patterns and activates different parts of our brains.
▶ The challenge is to move people from avoidance and justifications to emotional ambivalence, where they are processing emotions about the topic.

🎯 𝐌𝐨𝐯𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐦𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐨 𝐂𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐜 𝐅𝐫𝐚𝐦𝐞 🎯 

▶ There's a need to shift the conversation from a consumer frame (individual choices at the grocery store) to a civic frame (political engagement and voting).
▶ People's sense of futility often comes from viewing food choices as consumers rather than understanding the political aspects of their choices.
▶ Shifting to a civic frame involves combating civic futility, making people aware that societal change is crucial, and holding individuals accountable through citizen-initiated measures.

💙 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐄𝐦𝐨𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐏𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐝𝐨𝐱 💙

▶ While messages often seen as emotionally manipulative may be met with resistance, the issue at hand is fundamentally emotional.
▶ Strategies for emotional appeals include toning down language intensity, using pictures to convey emotions, and defending the value of emotions as data.
▶ Facts are important but are strengthened when paired with emotional appeals. Numerical facts, provided with citations, enhance the credibility of messages.

We're really excited to have been part of the Civil Service #Vegan Network's first conference! 🚀

Our Direction Lead, Dr. Laila Kassam, and Strategy Lead, Kangan Upadhye, had the opportunity to attend CSVN's first conference this month. During the event, we had the opportunity to share our ideas for building the power of the Animal Freedom movement and how our work at Animal Think Tank is contributing to this. ✊

🎯 We presented our work on building a network of local campaigning groups, our strategy research, our narrative research, and our efforts to build narrative and strategic unity in the UK movement ecology.

For example, connecting with the wider movement ecology, developing and promoting evidence-based policies to meet the government's climate, nature, health, and animal welfare goals, and scaling the network to normalise veganism in the civil service and build the network's power to effect wider change for animals.

Where does #NonViolence fit within a successful social movement? ✋

The goal of a social movement is simple: to change public opinion. But what exactly does the process of changing public opinion look like? The answer lies in momentum—a collective effort of many people taking escalating actions over time.🧏 It's kind of like a snowball rolling down a hill, growing larger along the way and attracting more supporters to the cause. 🚀

In a recent discussion with the Sentience Institute Podcast, our Direction Lead, Laila Kassam, PhD, elaborated on the role of non-violent direct action within the 'cycle of momentum', an organising model advocated by Mark and Paul Enger in 'This is an Uprising' to build mass protest movements:

She explained, "Movements grow cyclically, and the cycle of momentum consists of three parts: 𝙚𝙨𝙘𝙖𝙡𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣, 𝙖𝙗𝙨𝙤𝙧𝙥𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙞𝙣𝙘𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙨𝙚𝙙 𝙖𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙚, 𝙥𝙤𝙥𝙪𝙡𝙖𝙧 𝙨𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙩. When we talk about escalation, we're referring to the use of non-violent direct action to help trigger events. Multiple trigger events can create what we call moments of the whirlwind, or we can use non-violent direct action to be prepared to respond when trigger events occur naturally."

While some participants in the Animal Freedom movement are fulfilling elements of momentum organizing, a fully realized momentum-style social movement has not yet emerged. There is a question as to whether momentum organizing adequately synthesises mass protest and structure-based organizing to the extent claimed. Are there areas within the Animal Freedom movement that could fill this gap?

⤷Read our article on @medium/AnimalThinkTank to find out.

🎙️Listen to our talk with the Sentient Institute Podcast, you can find the link in the stories.

What does @animal_think_tank_ actually do? 

Here's a quick and simple answer from our co-founder, Dr Laila Kassam.

#PeoplePower #SocialMovement #SupportAnimalFreedom #SocialChangemakers #AnimalAdvocacy

Launched in 2018, Animal Think Tank came together as a group of people determined to build a broad-based movement for Animal Freedom based on social movement theory and cutting-edge strategy.

Since launching, we’ve trained hundreds of changemakers through Movement Building workshops in the UK, US and Canada. 

We also helped launch @animal_rebellion, an ally to @extinctionrebellion, who are seeking to push the issue of animal farming and fishing into the environmental movement’s focus.

We are in the process of scaling up to a team of 25+ and preparing to launch a mass movement organisation for Animal Freedom.
